Award.AwardTitle: Closed-Loop Experiment-Simulation Approach to Designer Materials: GaAsSbBi for Optoelectronics.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical description: There is a strong national need for efficient optoelectronic devices that operate in the infrared and far infrared regime. Applications for infrared sources and detectors include night vision and surveillance, wireless communication, and chemical and biological sensing. Most current infrared applications rely on expensive and hazardous materials. Bismuth containing III-V semiconductors are non-toxic and may be directly integrated into existing fabrication lines, further reducing cost. However, growing these materials is nontrivial due to the complex interactions of Bi with the other elements in these compounds. In this project, the growth and optical properties of Bi-containing compound semiconductors are examined with an eye on infrared detector applications. The mode in which this research is performed is also important, because it combines experimental and computational methods to speed the pace of discovery. This project also develops pedagogical modules that are used in a variety of situations, thus augmenting our infrastructure for education and broadening the participation of underrepresented groups in science and engineering related majors.

Technical description: The novelty of this research is in coupling experiments with computations when studying an unknown and highly complex alloy system. A calculate-verify cycle is used to establish the growth parameters and to obtain films that have the desired lattice parameter and band structure. ab initio statistical mechanics combines Density Functional Theory, cluster expansions, and statistical Monte-Carlo to calculate the equilibrium properties, including band structure of the GaAsSbBi alloy. In tandem, growth modeling based on kinetic Monte Carlo is used to understand deviations from equilibrium behavior. Robust experimental methods for the growth (Molecular Beam Epitaxy) and atomic-scale characterization (Atom Probe Tomography, X-Ray Diffraction, Rutherford Backscattering, etc) are employed. Using experiments coupled with computation greatly reduces parameter space and speed the path to optimization of this new class of materials suitable for infrared devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
III-V semiconductor alloys containing Bi, often referred to as bismides, have recently drawn attention because of their predicted properties related to the large bandgap reduction with increasing

Bi incorporation and large spin orbit bowing. Growth of bismides is quite challenging because Bi desorbs from the surface at typical growth temperatures, thus films need to be grown at a low temperature to incorporate any amount of Bi. Growth of these materials is further complicated by the formation of group III or Bi droplets. In this project, we have adopted an approach that couples experiment and computation to model the incorporation of Bi into these alloys.  Over the lifetime of the grant, we have been examining routes to improve the incorporation of Bi into GaAs and other III-V compound semiconductors. The major activities involve the growth of these high immiscible alloys, and characterization of the composition and any nonuniformities in the microstructures.  The specific objectives of this program were to incorporate as much Bi as possible into GaAs using our kinetic Monte Carlo results as a guide, and to characterize and understand the origin of compositional nonuniformities.   

 

Conditions that lead to surface droplets, regardless of composition exacerbate these effects, each via different proposed mechanisms. However, the possibility of harnessing these effects to design materials than can self-assemble high Bi content nano-structures remains. Specifically the observed nanowire like structures in samples with bi-phasic droplets.  Even droplet free films exhibit variations in the form of lateral composition modulation and cluster formation, the latter may be useful for quantum dot based devices. Despite this, these observations have provided many obstacles to the realization of uniform high content GaAsBi films. Particularly troublesome is the limited range of conditions that lead to droplet free growth, which was determined by the generation of a surface morphology phase map as a function of material flux ratios.  Finally, we were able to achieve droplet free films with compositions up to 13.5%, and films with Bi droplets up to 18%  though non-uniformities still remain a challenge.

 

One Ph. D thesis, two papers, a book chapter, six invited, and four contributed talks were created on these topics.   Several other papers are also in preparation, and at least two more Ph. D Theses will be generated using data generated from this project.
